comment: recommended in wild brews:68 for 1 week then 80 for 8 weeks or cellar for up to three years//temp 65 to 85, longer ferm will give a more attenuated and complex acid profile, a short warmer ferm will give more lactic acid//can substitute maize for unmalted wheat//can blend with cherries after 12-18 (some flanders do it after 6 months, but this recipe with the roeselare blend said to wait 12-18) months (leave on for 6-9 months)//can blend with a malty brown ale.
https://byo.com/grains/item/655-flanders-red-ale good info on bottling and additional recipes etc.
traditional: 122 20 min, 145 for 40, 162 for 30, 169 mashout for 10, sparge at 176

going for a step mash, in at 132, 140 at the bottom, 130s at the higher up part of the mash, stirred a lot, was heating a little and stayed around 140-150 from 15 to 30 min (some hot areas up above 165), stirred a lot, 1 1/4 hour mash, began sparging
wyeast says 18 months for full profile, brewed 1/17/15, taste next holiday season to see how it is doing
ended up with 4.5 gal of 1060, so didnt pull enough for a 1.5 hour boil,

low action primary, not what i expected from a belgian strain (slow building kraussen, never heated up, maybe I just started it too cold, pitched at 62ish), probs leave it for two weeks and then put in secondary to long term age with little to no head space
put in 5 gal a while back, added some water i boiled to top it off (so not 1060 any longer), its odd, it gets small krausen, then that stops and disappears, back and forth.
